709505f-a.text:
Sixth Ave., north from West 43rd Street to Central Park, and showing a general view northeast from the Bush Terminal Building (130 West 42nd Street, south side, between Sixth Ave. and Broadway). This view taken prior to the sudden building boom shows the Plaza Hotel, the Sherry Netherland, the Ritz Tower, St, Patrick's Cathedral, the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas and B.F. Keith's Hippodrome (Sixth Ave., east side, between West 43rd and 44th Streets). Also shown are the Queensboro and the Hellgate
R.R. Bridges.
May 1926.
Brown Brothers.

709495f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, at the N. E. corner ef W. 43rd Street, showing a pertien of the Hippodrome, a theatrical structure under demelitien. This is the first majer real estate eperation resulting from the
recent razing ef the Sixth Avenue "El'.
Oct. 9, 1939
Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New Yerk Public Library
.;iA(2(S

709497f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from W. 43rd to 44th Streets, showing the Hippodrome occupying this frontage. As apparent, this land mark is under demolition and the site will be cleared for use as a parking lot. At the right margin is a portion of the R. C. A.
Building.
September 17, 1939
George Jiranek
New York Public Library
Photostat Division

709498f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, frem W. 43rd te 44th Streets, shewing the Hippedreme under demolitien.

709501f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, from W. 43ro to 44th Streets, showing the former Hippodrome site. This has been cleared and will be utilized as an automobile pakrking lot. The photographer is viewing southeastward towards buildings on the north side of
44th Street that are east of the Avenue.
November 15, 1939
Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

709503f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from West 43rd Street, showing the Hippodrome and Rockefeller Center buildings. The former, shown solely in View 2, is shortly to be demolished and its site utilized as an automobile parking lot.
View 1: March 29, 1939
View 2: September 8, 1939
P. L. Sperr

709507f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, from West 43rd to 44th Streets, showing the low buildings on the west side,as viewed across the former Hippodrome site. The latter has become the parking lot shown. This occupies the easterly frontage of the Avenue. Times Square and Broadway are just beyond, distinguished by the dominant Paramount Building. Vcrious hotels are on the side streets. Observable are the 44th Street HHotel, the Hotel Langwell, the Peerless and the St James.
View 3 is northwestward towards W. 44th Street.
May 5, 1940
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr

709499f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, from W. 43rd to 44th Streets,
showing tne Hippodrome under demolition. Note the pavement of the Avenue, which at this date is still going thru subway construction, car tracks remain, tho busses have replaced the former surface cars.
November 1, 1939
Cnift of deorge Jiranek
New York Public Library
E98P8898989S8:

709504f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, from West 43rd
to 44th Street's, showing prominently the old Hlppodromme. This structure erected aboot 1912, housed rany fammous productions, from pageants to talking pictures. Famous artiats icluding Taderewski hhave played here. In 1922, Richard Straus conducted a series of concerts with the Philadelphia Orchestra. Prior to its demolition in the Fall of 1939, tt was a motion picture house. Vrious sport af'a'rs wore held here.
View 1: March 9, 1929
2: 'ay 27, 1930
3: May 1, 1933

709509f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, west side, from West 44th (center) to 43rd Streets. This photograph, taken from the east side of the Avenue is in s southwestward direction to show towering structures at 42nd Street. They are the dominant Bush Building and the No. 113
W. 42nd 5treet Building.
View 2 is photographed across the parking lot where the former Hippodrome stood. The low 6th Avenue buildings in this view are at 43rd Street. To the left is a portion of Stern's Department Store. The white 33-story, No. 1441 Broadway Building is included.
View 1: April 5, 1239
View 2: May 1940
P. L. Sperr
wr mRROgIUCTION9
